play.title: A Pleasant Comedy of Fair Em

edition.title: A Pleasant COMEDIE OF FAIRE EM, The Millers Daughter of Manchester: With the loue of William the Conqueror.
A Pleasant COMEDIE OF FAIRE EM, The Millers Daughter of Manchester: With the loue of William the Conqueror.

stagedir.dir: Enter William the Conqueror, Marquis of Lubeck, with a picture, Mountney, Manvile, Vallingford, and Duke Dirot.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: What means fair Britain’s mighty conqueror
So suddenly to cast away his staff,
And all in passion to forsake the tilt?

speech.speaker: DIROT.
speech.line: My lord, this triumph we solemnize here,
Is of mere love to your increasing joys;
Only expecting cheerful looks for all.
What sudden pangs than move your majesty
To dim the brightness of the day with frowns?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Ah, good my lords, misconster not the cause;
At least, suspect not my displeasèd brows:
I amorously do bear to your intent,
For thanks; and all that you can wish, I yield.
But that which makes me blush and shame to tell,
Is cause why thus I turn my conquering eyes
To coward’s looks and beaten fantasies.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Since we are guiltless, we the less dismay
To see this sudden change possess your cheer;
For if it issue from your own conceits,
Bred by suggestion of some envious thoughts,
Your highness’ wisdom may suppress it straight.
Yet tell us, good my lord, what thought it is
That thus bereaves you of your late content?
That in advise we may assist your grace,
Or bend our forces to revive your spirits.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Ah, Marquis Lubeck, in thy power it lies
To rid my bosom of these thralled dumps:
And therefore, good my lords, forbear awhile
That we may parley of these private cares,
Whose strength subdues me more than all the world.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: We go, and wish the private conference
Public effects, in this accustomed peace.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all but William, and Lubeck.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Now, Marquis, must a conqueror at arms
Disclose himself thralled to unarmèd thoughts,
And, threatened of a shadow, yield to lust.
No sooner had my sparkling eyes beheld
The flames of beauty blazing on this piece,
But suddenly a sense of miracle,
Imagined on thy lovely mistress’ face,
Made me abandon bodily regard,
And cast all pleasures on my wounded soul:
Then, gentle Marquis, tell me what she is,
That thus thou honorest on thy warlike shield;
And if thy love and interest be such
As justly may give place to mine,—
That if it be, my soul with honor’s wings
May fly into the bosom of my dear;’
If not, close them and stoop into my grave.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: If this be all, renownèd conqueror,
Advance your drooping spirits, and revive
The wonted courage of your conquering mind;
For this fair picture painted on my shield
Is the true counterfeit of lovely Blanch,
Princess and daughter to the king of Danes,
Whose beauty and excess of ornaments
Deserves another manner of defense,
Pomp and high person to attend her state
Then Marquis Lubeck any way presents;
Therefore her virtues I resign to thee,
Already shrined in thy religious breast,
To be advanced and honored to the full,
Nor bear I this an argument of love,
But to renown fair Blanch, my sovereign’s child,
In every place where I by arms may do it.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Ah, Marquis, thy words bring heaven unto my soul!
And had I heaven to give for thy reward,
Thou shouldst be throned in no unworthy place—
But let my uttermost wealth suffice thy worth,
Which here I vow: and to aspire the bliss
That hangs on quick achievement of my love,
Thyself and I will travel in disguise,
To bring this lady to our Britain court.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Let William but bethink what may avail,
And let me die if I deny my aid.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Then thus:—The Duke Dirot, and th’ Earl Dimarch,
Will I leave substitutes to rule my realm,
While mighty love forbids my being here;
And in the name of Sir Robert of Windsor
Will go with thee unto the Danish court.
Keep William’s secrets, Marquis, if thou love him.
Bright Blanch, I come! Sweet fortune, favor me,
And I will laud thy name eternally!

scene.scenelocation: The cottage of the Miller of Manchester.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Miller and Em, his daughter.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Come, daughter, we must learn to shake off pomp,
To leave the state that erst beseem’d a knight,
And gentlemen of no mean descent,
To undertake this homely miller’s trade:
Thus must we mask to save our wretched lives,
Threatened by conquest of this hapless isle,
Whose sad invasion by the conqueror,
Have made a number such as we subject
Their gentle necks unto the stubborn yoke
Of drudging labor and base peasantry.
Sir Thomas Goddard now old Goddard is,
Goddard the miller of fair Manchester.
Why should not I content me with this state,
As good Sir Edmund Trafford did the flail?
And thou, sweet Em, must stoop from high estate
To join with mine, that thus we may protect
Our harmless lives, which, led in greater port,
Would be an envious object to our foes,
That seek to root all Britain’s gentry
From bearing countenance against their tyranny.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Good father, let my full resolvèd thoughts,
With settled patience to support this chance,
Be some poor comfort to your agèd soul;
For therein rests the height of my estate—
That you are pleased with this dejection,—
And that all toils my hands may undertake
May serve to work your worthiness content.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Thanks, my dear daughter; these thy pleasant words
Transfer my soul into a second heaven:
And in thy settled mind my joys consist,
My state revived, and I in former plight.
Although our outward pomp be thus abased,
And thralled to drudging, stayless of the world,
Let us retain those honorable minds
That lately governed our superior state,
Wherein true gentry is the only mean
That makes us differ from base millers born.
Though we expect no knightly delicates,
Nor thirst in soul for former sovereignty,
Yet may our minds as highly scorn to stoop
To base desires of vulgar’s worldliness,
As if we were in our precedent way.
And, lovely daughter, since thy youthful years
Must needs admit as young affections,
And that sweet love impartial perceives
Her dainty subjects through every part,
In chief receive these lessons from my lips,
The true discoverers of a virgin’s due,
Now requisite, now that I know thy mind
Something inclined to favor Manvile’s suit,
A gentleman, thy lover in protest;
And that thou mayst not be by love deceived,
But try his meaning fit for thy desert,
In pursuit of all amorous desires,
Regard thine honor. Let not vehement sighs,
Nor earnest vows importing fervent love,
Render thee subject to the wrath of lust:
For that, transformed to former sweet delight,
Will bring thy body and thy soul to shame.
Chaste thoughts and modest conversations,
Of proof to keep out all enchanting vows,
Vain sighs, forced tears, and pitiful aspects,
Are they that make deformèd ladies fair,
And poor ones rich; and such enticing men,
That seek of all but only present grace,
Shall in persèv’rance of a virgin’s vow
Prefer the most refusers to the choice
Of such a soul as yielded what they sought.
But ho, where is Trotter?

stagedir.dir: Enter Trotter, the Miller’s man, to them; and they within call to him for their grist.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Where’s Trotter? Why, Trotter is here. I’faith, you and your daughter go up and down weeping and wamanting, and keeping of a wamentation, as who should say, the mill would go with your wamenting.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: How now, Trotter, why complainest thou?

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Why, yonder is a company of young men and maids, keep such a stir for their grist, that they would have it before my stones be ready to grind it. But, i’faith, I would I could break wind enough backward: you should not tarry for your grist, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Content thee, Trotter, I’ll go pacify them.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: I wish you will when I cannot. Why look, you have a mill—why, what’s your mill without me? Or rather, mistress what were I without you?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Nay, Trotter, if you fall a-chiding, I will give you over.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: I chide you, dame, to amend you. You are too fine to be a miller’s daughter. For if you should but stoop to take up the toll-dish, you will have the cramp in your finger at least ten weeks after.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Ah, well said, Trotter. Teach her to play the good housewife, and thou shalt have her to thy wife, if thou canst get her good will.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Ah, words wherein I see matrimony come laden with kisses to salute me: now let me alone to pick the mill, to fill the hopper, to take the toll, to mend the sails, yea, and to make the mill go with the very force of my love.

stagedir.dir: They call for their grist within.

speech.line: I come, I come! I’faith, now you shall have your grist, or else Trotter will trot and amble himself to death.

stagedir.dir: Enter King of Denmark, with some Attendants; Blanch, his Daughter, Mariana, Marquis of Lubeck, and William the Conqueror, disguised.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Lord Marquis Lubeck, welcome home.
Welcome, brave knight, unto the Denmark king,
For William’s sake, the noble Norman duke,
So famous for his fortunes and success,
That graceth him with name of Conqueror;
Right double welcome must thou be to us.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: And to my lord the king shall I recount
Your grace’s courteous entertainment,
That for his sake vouchsafe to honor me,
A simple knight, attendant on his grace.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: But say, sir knight, what may I call your name?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Robert Windsor, and like your majesty.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: I tell thee, Robert, I so admire the man,
As that I count it heinous guilt in him
That honors not Duke William with his heart.
Blanch, bid this stranger welcome, good my girl.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: Sir, should I neglect your highness’ charge herein,
It might be thought of base discourtesy.
Welcome, sir knight, to Denmark, heartily.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Thanks, gentle lady. Lord Marquis, what is she?

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: That same is Blanch, the daughter to the king,
The substance of the shadow that you saw.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: May this be she for whom I crossed the seas?
I am ashamed to think I was so fond—
In whom there’s nothing that contents my mind—
Ill head, worse featured, uncomely, nothing courtly;
Swart and ill-favored, a collier’s sanguine skin:—
I never saw a harder favored slut.
Love her? For what? I can no whit abide her!

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Mariana, I have this day received letters
From Swethia, that lets me understand
Your ransom is collecting there with speed,
And shortly shall be hither sent to us.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Not that I find occasion to mislike
My entertainment in your grace’s court,
But that I long to see my native home.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: And reason have you, madam, for the same.
Lord Marquis, I commit unto your charge
The entertainment of Sir Robert here;
Let him remain with you within the court,
In solace and disport to spend the time.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: I thank your highness, whose bounden I remain.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: Unhappy Blanch, what strange effects are these
That work within my thoughts confusedly?
That still, methinks, affection draws me on,
To take, to like, nay more, to love this knight.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: A modest countenance, no heavy sullen look,
Not very fair, but richly decked with favor;
A sweet face, an exceeding dainty hand;
A body, were it framed of wax
By all the cunning artists of the world,
It could not better be proportioned.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: How now, Sir Robert? In a study, man?
Here is no time for contemplation.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: My lord, there is a certain odd conceit,
Which on the sudden greatly troubles me.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: How like you Blanch? I partly do perceive
The little boy hath played the wag with you.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: The more I look the more I love to look.
Who says that Mariana is not fair?
I’ll gage my gauntlet ‘gainst the envious man,
That dares avow there liveth her compare.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Sir Robert, you mistake your counterfeit—
This is the lady which you came to see.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Yea, my lord, she is counterfeit indeed:
For there’s the substance that best contents me.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: That is my love. Sir Robert, you do wrong me.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: The better for you, sir, she is your love.
As for the wrong, I see not how it grows.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: In seeking that which is another’s right.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: As who should say your love were privileged,
That none might look upon her but yourself.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: These jars becomes not our familiarity,
Nor will I stand on terms to move your patience.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Why, my lord,
Am not I of flesh and blood as well as you?
Then give me leave to love as well as you.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: To love, Sir Robert; but whom? Not she I love.
Nor stands it with the honor of my state
To brook corrivals with me in my love.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: So, sir, we are thorough for that love.
Ladies, farewell. Lord Marquis, will you go?
I’ll find a time to speak with her I trow.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: With all my heart. Come, ladies, will you walk?

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Ah, Em! The subject of my restless thoughts—
The anvil whereupon my heart doth beat,
Framing thy state to thy desert—
Full ill this life becomes thy heavenly look,
Wherein sweet love and virtue sit enthroned—
Bad world, where riches is esteemed above them both;
In whose base eyes nought else is bountiful!
A miller’s daughter, says the multitude,
Should not be loved of a gentleman—
But let them breathe their souls into the air,
Yet will I still affect thee as myself,
So thou be constant in thy plighted vow.
But here comes one—I’ll listen to his talk.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Go, William Conqueror, and seek thy love—
Seek thou a minion in a foreign land,
Whilst I draw back and court my love at home.
The miller’s daughter of fair Manchester
Hath bound my feet to this delightsome soil,
And from her eyes do dart such golden beams
That holds my heart in her subjection.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: He ruminates on my belovèd choice:
God grant he come not to prevent my hope.
But here’s another; him I’ll listen to.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Nature unjust, in utterance of thy art,
To grace a peasant with a prince’s fame!
Peasant am I, so to misterm my love:
Although a miller’s daughter by her birth,
Yet may her beauty and her virtues well suffice
To hide the blemish of her birth in hell,
Where neither envious eyes nor thought can pierce,
But endless darkness ever smother it.
Go, William Conqueror, and seek thy love,
Whilst I draw back and court mine own the while,
Decking her body with such costly robes
As may become her beauty’s worthiness;
That so thy labors may be laughed to scorn,
And she thou seekest out in foreign regions,
Be darkened and eclipsed when she arrives,
By one that I have chosen nearer home.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: What comes he too, to intercept my love?
Then hie thee, Manvile, to forestall such foes.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: What now, Lord Vallingford, are you behind?
The king hath chosen you to go with him.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: So chose he you; therefore I marvel much
That both of us should linger in this sort.
What may the king imagine of our stay?

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: The king may justly think we are to blame:
But I imagined I might well be spared,
And that no other man had borne my mind.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: The like did I: in friendship then resolve
What is the cause of your unlooked-for stay.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Lord Vallingford, I tell thee as a friend,
Love is the cause why I have stayed behind.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Love, my lord, of whom?

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Em, the miller’s daughter of Manchester.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: But may this be?

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Why not, my lord? I hope full well you know
That love respects no difference of state,
So beauty serve to stir affection.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: But this it is that makes me wonder most,
That you and I should be of one conceit,
In such a strange unlikely passion.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: But is that true? My lord, I hope you do but jest.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I would I did; then were my grief the less.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Nay, never grieve; for if the cause be such,
To join our thoughts in such a sympathy,
All envy set aside. Let us agree
To yield to either’s fortune in this choice.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Content, say I: and whatsoe’er befall,
Shake hands, my lord, and fortune thrive at all.

scene.scenelocation: The country near the Miller’s Cottage.

stagedir.dir: Enter Em and Trotter, the Miller’s man, with a kerchief on his head and a urinal in his hand.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Trotter, where have you been?

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Where have I been? Why, what signifies this?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: A kerchief, doth it not?

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: What call you this, I pray?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: I say it is an urinal.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Then this is mystically to give you to understand
I have been at the Phismicary’s house.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: How long hast thou been sick?

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: I’faith, e’en as long as I have not been half well, and that hath been a long time.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: A loitering time, I rather imagine.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: It may be so: but the Phismicary tells me that you can help me.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Why, anything I can do for recovery of thy health, be right well assured of.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Then give me your hand.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: To what end?

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: That the ending of an old indenture is the beginning of a new bargain.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: What bargain?

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: That you promised to do anything to recover my health.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: On that condition I give thee my hand.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Ah, sweet Em!

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: How now, Trot! Your master’s daughter?

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: I’faith, I am at the fairest. Ah, Em, sweet Em!
Fresh as the flower,
That hath the power
To wound my heart,
And ease my smart,
Of me, poor thief, in prison bound.—

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: So all your rhyme lies on the ground.
But what means this?

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Ah, mark the device—
For thee, my love, full sick I was, in hazard of my life,
Thy promise was to make me whole, and for to be my wife.
Let me enjoy my love, my dear,
And thou possess thy Trotter here.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: But I meant no such matter.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Yes, woos, but you did. I’ll go to our parson Sir John, and he shall mumble up the marriage out of hand.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: But here comes one that will forbid the bands.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Ah, sir, you come too late.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: What remedy, Trotter?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Go, Trotter, my father calls.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Would you have me go in, and leave you two here?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Why, darest thou not trust me?

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Yes, faith, e’en as long as I see you.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Go thy ways, I pray thee heartily.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: That same word, heartily, is of great force. I will go, but I pray, sir, beware you. Come not too near the wench.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: I am greatly beholding to you.—
Ah, mistress, sometime I might have said, my love,
But time and fortune hath bereaved me of that,
And I am abject in those gracious eyes,
That with remorse erst saw into my grief,—
May sit and sigh the sorrows of my heart.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Indeed my Manvile hath some cause to doubt,
When such a swain is rival in his love.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Ah, Em, were he the man that causeth this mistrust,
I should esteem of thee as at the first.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: But is my love in earnest all this while?

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Believe me, Em, it is not time to jest,
When others ’joy what lately I possessed.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: If, touching love, my Manvile charge me thus,
Unkindly must I take it at his hands,
For that my conscience clears me of offense.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Ah, impudent and shameless in thy ill,
That, with thy cunning and defraudful tongue,
Seeks to delude the honest meaning mind!
Was never heard in Manchester before,
Of truer love than hath been betwixt us twain:
And for my part, how I have hazarded
Displeasure of my father and my friends,
Thyself can witness; yet notwithstanding this,
Two gentlemen attending on duke William,
Mountney and Vallingford, as I heard them named,
Oft times resort to see and to be seen,
Walking the street fast by thy father’s door,
Whose glancing eyes up to the windows cast
Give testies of their master’s amorous heart.
This, Em, is noted and too much talked on;
Some see it without mistrust of ill,
Others there are that, scorning, grin thereat,
And saith, “There goes the miller’s daughter’s wooers”.
Ah me! Whom chiefly and most of all it doth concern,
To spend my time in grief and vex my soul,
To think my love should be rewarded thus,
And for thy sake abhor all womankind!

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: May not a maiden look upon a man
Without suspicious judgment of the world?

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: If sight do move offense, it is the better not to see:
But thou didst more, unconstant as thou art,
For with them thou hadst talk and conference.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: May not a maid talk with a man without mistrust?

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Not with such men suspected amorous.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: I grieve to see my Manvile’s jealousy.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Ah, Em, faithful love is full of jealousy.
So did I love thee true and faithfully,
For which I am rewarded most unthankfully.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: And so away? What, in displeasure gone,
And left me such a bitter sweet to gnaw upon?
Ah, Manvile, little wottest thou
How near this parting goeth to my heart.
Uncourteous love, whose followers reap reward,
Of hate, disdain, reproach, and infamy,
The fruit of frantic, bedlam jealousy!
But here comes one of these suspicious men:
Witness, my God, without desert of me,
For only Manvile honor I in heart,
Nor shall unkindness cause me from him to start.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: For this good fortune, Venus be thou blessed,
To meet my love, the mistress of my heart,
Where time and place gives opportunity,
At full to let her understand my love.

stagedir.dir: He turns to Em, and offers to take her hand; she goes from him.

speech.line: Fair mistress, since my fortune sorts so well,
Hear you a word. What meaneth this?
Nay, stay, fair Em.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: I am going homewards, sir.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Yet stay, sweet love, to whom I must disclose
The hidden secrets of a lover’s thoughts,
Not doubting but to find such kind remorse
As naturally you are inclined to.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: The gentleman, your friend, sir,
I have not seen him this four days, at the least.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: What’s that to me?
I speak not, sweet, in person of my friend,
But for myself, whom, if that love deserve
To have regard, being honorable love,
Not base effects of loose lascivious love,
Whom youthful wantons play and dally with,
But that unites in honorable bands of holy rites,
And knits the sacred knot that gods—

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: What mean you, sir, to keep me here so long?
I cannot understand you by your signs;
You keep a-prattling with your lips,
But never a word you speak that I can hear.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: What, is she deaf? A great impediment!
Yet remedies there are for such defects.
Sweet Em, it is no little grief to me,
To see where nature in her pride of art,
Hath wrought perfections rich and admirable—

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Speak you to me, sir?

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: To thee, my only joy.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: I cannot hear you.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Oh, plague of fortune! Oh, hell without compare!
What boots it us to gaze and not enjoy?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Fare you well, sir.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Farewell, my love, nay, farewell life and all!
Could I procure redress for this infirmity,
It might be means she would regard my suit.
I am acquainted with the king’s physicians,
Amongst the which there’s one, mine honest friend,
Signor Alberto, a very learnèd man;
His judgment will I have to help this ill.
Ah, Em, fair Em, if art can make thee whole,
I’ll buy that sense for thee, although it cost me dear.
But, Mountney, stay; this may be but deceit,
A matter feigned only to delude thee,
And, not unlike, perhaps by Vallingford.
He loves fair Em as well as I—
As well as I? Ah, no, not half so well—
Put case: yet may he be thine enemy,
And give her counsel to dissemble thus.
I’ll try the event, and if it fall out so,
Friendship, farewell: love makes me now a foe.

scene.scenelocation: An antechamber at the Danish Court.

stagedir.dir: Enter Marquis of Lubeck and Mariana.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Trust me, my lord, I’m sorry for your hurt.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Gramercy, madam, but it is not great;
Only a thrust, pricked with a rapier’s point.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: How grew the quarrel, my lord?

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Sweet lady, for thy sake. There was, this last night, two masks in our company, myself the foremost, the others strangers were. Amongst the which, when the music began to sound the measures, each masker made choice of his lady. And one, more forward than the rest, stepped towards thee, which I perceiving, thrust him aside and took thee myself. But this was taken in so ill part, that at my coming out of the court gate, with justling together it was my chance to be thrust into the arm. The doer thereof, because he was the original cause of the disorder at that inconvenient time, was presently committed, and is this morning sent for to answer the matter. And I think here he comes. What, Sir Robert of Windsor, how now?

stagedir.dir: Enter Keeper with William disguised as Sir Robert of Windsor.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: I’faith, my lord, a prisoner. But what ails your arm?

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Hurt the last night, by mischance.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: What, not in the mask at the court gate?

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Yes, trust me, there.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Why, then, my lord, I thank you for my night’s lodging.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: And I for my hurt, if it were so. Keeper, away. I discharge you of your prisoner.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Lord Marquis, you offered me disgrace to shoulder me.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Sir, I knew you not, and therefore you must pardon me: and the rather, it might be alleged to me of mere simplicity to see another dance with my mistress, disguised, and I myself in presence. But seeing it was our haps to damnify each other unwillingly, let us be content with our harms, and lay the fault where it was, and so become friends.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: I’faith, I am content with my night’s lodging, if you be content with your hurt.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Not content that I have it, but content to forget how I came by it.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: My lord, here comes Lady Blanch. Let's away.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: With good will. Lady, you will stay?

stagedir.dir: Exit Lubeck and William disguised as Sir Robert of Windsor.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Madam—

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: Mariana, as I am grieved with thy presence, so am I not offended for thy absence; and, were it not a breach to modesty, thou shouldst know before I left thee.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: How near is this humor to madness? If you hold on as you begin, you are in a pretty way to scolding.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: To scolding, huswife?

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Madam, here comes one.

stagedir.dir: Enters a Messenger with a letter.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: There doth indeed. Fellow, wouldst thou have any thing with anybody here?

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: I have a letter to deliver to the Lady Mariana.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: Give it me.

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: There must none but she have it.

stagedir.dir: Blanch snatcheth the letter from him.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: Go to, foolish fellow, and therefore, to ease the anger I sustain, I’ll be so bold to open it. What’s here? Sir Robert greets you well! You, mistress, his love, his life! Oh, amorous man! How he entertains his new mistress, and bestows on Lubeck, his odd friend, a horn nightcap to keep in his wit.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Madam, though you have discourteously read my letter, yet, I pray you, give it me.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: Then take it, there, and there, and there.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: How far doth this differ from modesty! Yet will I gather up the pieces, which, haply, may show to me the intent thereof, though not the meaning.

stagedir.dir: She gathers up the pieces and joins them.

speech.line: “Your servant and love, Sir Robert of Windsor, alias William the Conqueror, wisheth long health and happiness.”— Is this William the Conqueror shrouded under the name of Sir Robert of Windsor? Were he monarch of the world he should not dispossess Lubeck of his love. Therefore I will to the court, and there, if I can, close to be friends with Lady Blanch. And thereby keep Lubeck, my love, for myself, and further the Lady Blanch in her suit as much as I may.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Ah, Jealousy, that sharps the lover’s sight,
And makes him conceive and conster his intent,
Hath so bewitched my lovely Manvile’s senses
That he misdoubts his Em, that loves his soul.
He doth suspect corrivals in his love:
Which how untrue it is, be judge, my God!
But now no more: here comes Vallingford,
Shift him off now, as thou hast done the other.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: See how fortune presents me with the hope I looked for. Fair Em!

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Who’s that?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I am Vallingford, thy love and friend.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: I cry you mercy, sir. I thought so by your speech.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: What aileth thine eyes?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Oh blind, sir, blind. Stricken blind, by mishap, on a sudden.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: But is it possible you should be taken on such a sudden? Unfortunate Vallingford, to be thus crossed in thy love! Fair Em, I am not a little sorry to see this thy hard hap. Yet nevertheless, I am acquainted with a learned physician, that will do anything for thee at my request. To him will I resort, and enquire his judgment as concerning the recovery of so excellent a sense.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Oh Lord, sir! And of all things, I cannot abide physic. The very name thereof to me is odious.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: No? Not the thing will do thee so much good? Sweet Em, hither I came to parley of love, hoping to have found thee in thy wonted prosperity; and have the gods so unmercifully thwarted my expectation, by dealing so sinisterly with thee, sweet Em?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Good sir, no more. It fits not me
To have respect to such vain fantasies,
As idle love presents my ears withal.
More reason I should ghostly give my life
To sacred prayers, for this my former sin,
For which this plague is justly fall’n upon me,
Than hearken to the vanities of love.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Yet, sweet Em, accept this jewel at my hand,
Which I bestow on thee in token of my love.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: A jewel, sir! What pleasure can I have
In jewels, treasure, or any worldly thing
That want mine sight that should discern thereof?
Ah, sir, I must leave you,
The pain of mine eyes is so extreme,
I cannot long stay in a place. I take my leave.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Zounds, what a cross is this to my conceit. But, Vallingford, search the depth of this device. Why may not this be come feigned subtlety, by Mountney’s invention, to the intent that I, seeing such occasion, should leave off my suit, and not any more persist to solicit her of love? I’ll try the event; if I can by any means perceive the effect of this deceit to be procured by his means, friend Mountney, the one of us is like to repent our bargain.

stagedir.dir: Enter Mariana and Marquis of Lubeck.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Lady, since that occasion, forward in our good,
Presenteth place and opportunity,
Let me entreat your wonted kind consent
And friendly furtherance in a suit I have.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: My lord, you know you need not to entreat,
But may command Mariana to her power,
Be’t no impeachment to my honest fame.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Free are my thoughts from such base villainy
As may in question, lady, call your name;
Yet is the matter of such consequence,
Standing upon my honorable credit,
To be effected with such zeal and secrecy
As, should I speak and fail my expectation,
It would redound greatly to my prejudice.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: My lord, wherein hath Mariana
Given you occasion that you should mistrust,
Or else be jealous of my secrecy?

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Mariana, do not misconster me:
I not mistrust thee nor thy secrecy;
Nor let my love misconster my intent,
Nor think thereof but well and honorable.
Thus stands the case:—
Thou know’st from England hither came with me
Robert of Windsor, a noble man at arms,
Lusty and valiant, in spring time of his years;
No marvel then though he prove amorous.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: True, my lord, he came to see fair Blanch.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: No, Mariana, that is not it:—his love to Blanch
Was then extinct, when first he saw thy face.
Tis thee he loves: yea, thou art only she
That’s mistress and commander of his thoughts.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Well, well, my lord, I like you; for such drifts
Put silly ladies often to their shifts.
Oft have I heard you say you loved me well,
Yea, sworn the same, and I believed you too.
Can this be found an action of good faith,
Thus to dissemble where you found true love?

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Mariana, I not dissemble on mine honor,
Nor fails my faith to thee; but for my friend,
For princely William, by whom thou shalt possess
The title of estate and majesty,
Fitting the love and virtues of thy mind,—
For him I speak, for him do I entreat,
And, with thy favor, fully do resign
To him the claim and interest of my love.
Sweet Mariana, then, deny me not;
Love William, love my friend, and honor me,
Who else is clean dishonored by thy means.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Born to mishap, myself am only she
On whom the sun of fortune never shined:
But planets ruled by retrograde aspect,
Foretold my ill in my nativity.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Sweet lady, cease, let my entreaty serve
To pacify the passion of thy grief,
Which well I know proceeds of ardent love.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: But Lubeck now regards not Mariana.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Even as my life, so love I Mariana.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Why do you post me to another, then?

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: He is my friend, and I do love the man.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Then, will Duke William rob me of my love?

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: No, as his life Mariana he doth love.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Speak for yourself, my lord, let him alone.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: So do I, madam, for he and I are one.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Then loving you, I do content you both.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: In loving him, you shall content us both:
Me, for I crave that favor at your hands,
Him, for he hopes that comfort at your hands.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Leave off, my lord, here comes the Lady Blanch.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Hard hap to break us off our talk so soon!
Sweet Mariana, do remember me.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Thy Mariana cannot chose but remember thee.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: Mariana, well met. You are very forward in your love.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Madam, be it in secret spoken to yourself, if you will but follow the complot I have invented, you will not think me so forward as yourself shall prove fortunate.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: As how?

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Madam, as thus. It is not unknown to you that Sir Robert of Windsor, a man that you do not a little esteem, hath long importuned me of love: but rather than I will be found false or unjust to the Marquis Lubeck, I will, as did the constant lady Penelope, undertake to effect some great task.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: What of all this?

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: The next time that Sir Robert shall come in his wonted sort, to solicit me with love, I will seem to agree, and like of anything that the knight shall demand, so far forth as it be no impeachment to my chastity. And to conclude, ’point some place for to meet the man, for my conveyance from the Denmark court, which determined upon, he will appoint some certain time for our departure, whereof you having intelligence, you may soon set down a plot to wear the English crown, and then—

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: What then?

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: If Sir Robert prove a king and you his queen, how then?

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: Were I assured of the one, as I am persuaded of the other, there were some possibility in it. But here comes the man.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Madam, begone, and you shall see I’ll work to your desire and my content.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Lady, this is well and happily met;
For fortune hitherto hath beene my foe,
And though I have oft sought to speak with you,
Yet still I have been crossed with sinister haps.
I cannot, madam, tell a loving tale,
Or court my mistress with fabulous discourses,
That am a soldier sworn to follow arms;
But this I bluntly let you understand,
I honor you with such religious zeal
As may become an honorable mind.
Nor may I make my love the siege of Troy,
That am a stranger in this country.
First, what I am I know you are resolved,
For that my friend hath let you understand,
The Marquis Lubeck, to whom I am so bound
That whilst I live I count me only his.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Surely you are beholding to the marquis,
For he hath been an earnest spokesman in your cause.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: And yields my lady then, at his request,
To grace Duke William with her gracious love?

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: My lord, I am a prisoner, and hard it were to get me from the court.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: An easy matter to get you from thee court,
If case that you will thereto give consent.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: Put case I should, how would you use me then?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Not otherwise but well and honorably.
I have at sea a ship that doth attend,
Which shall forthwith conduct us into England;
Where, when we are, I straight will marry thee.
We may not stay deliberating long,
Lest that suspicion, conscious of our weal,
Set in a foot to hinder our pretense.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: But this I think were most convenient,
To mask my face, the better to ’scape unknown.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: A good device. Till then farewell, fair love.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: But this I must entreat your grace,
You would not seek by lust unlawfully
To wrong my chaste determinations.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: I hold that man most shameless in his sin,
That seeks to wrong an honest lady’s name,
Whom he thinks worthy of his marriage bed.

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: In hope your oath is true,
I leave your grace till the appointed time.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Oh, happy William, blessèd in thy love,
Most fortunate in Mariana’s love!
Well, Lubeck, well, this courtesy of thine
I will requite, if God permit me life.

scene.scenelocation: England. The country near the English Court.

stagedir.dir: Enter Vallingford and Mountney at two sundry doors.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Vallingford, so hardly I disgest an injury
Thou’st profferd me, as, were’t not I detest
To do what stands not with the honor of my name,
Thy death should pay the ransom of thy fault.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: And, Mountney, had not my revenging wrath,
Incensed with more than ordinary love,
Been such for to deprive thee of thy life,
Thou hadst not lived to brave me as thou dost.
Wretch as thou art,
Wherein hath Vallingford offended thee?
That honorable bond which late we did
Confirm in presence of the gods,
When with the Conqueror we arrivèd here,
For my part hath been kept inviolably.
Till, now, too much abused by thy villainy,
I am enforced to cancel all those bands,
By hating him which I so well did love.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Subtle thou art, and cunning in thy fraud,
That giving me occasion of offense,
Thou pick’st a quarrel to excuse thy shame.
Why, Vallingford, was it not enough for thee
To be a rival ’twixt me and my love,
But counsel her, to my no small disgrace,
That when I came to talk with her of love,
She should seem deaf, as feigning not to hear.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: But hath she, Mountney, used thee as thou sayest?

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Thou knowest too well she hath—wherein
Thou couldst not do me greater injury.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Then I perceive we are deluded both;
For when I offered many gifts of gold,
And jewels to entreat for love,
She hath refused them with a coy disdain,
Alleging that she could not see the sun.
The same conjectured I to be thy drift,
That feigning so she might be rid of me.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: The like did I by thee. But are not these
Natural impediments?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: In my conjecture merely counterfeit;
Therefore let’s join hands, in friendship once again,
Since that the jar grew only by conjecture.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: With all my heart: yet let’s try the truth thereof.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: With right good will. We will straight unto her father,
And there to learn whether it be so or no.

stagedir.dir: Enter William the Conqueror and Blanch disguised with a mask over her face.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Come on, my love, the comfort of my life.
Disguisèd thus, we may remain unknown,
And get we once to sea, I force not then;
We quickly shall attain the English shore.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: But this I urge you with your former oath,
You shall not seek to violate mine honor,
Until our marriage rights be all performed.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Mariana, here I swear to thee by heaven,
And by the honor that I bear to arms,
Never to seek or crave at hands of thee
The spoil of honorable chastity,
Until we do attain the English coast,
Where thou shalt be my right espousèd queen.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: In hope your oath proceedeth from your heart,
Let’s leave the court, and betake us to His power
That governs all things to his mighty will,
And will reward the just with endless joy,
And plague the bad with most extreme annoy.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Lady, as little tarriance as we may,
Lest some misfortune happen by the way.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Miller, his man Trotter, and Manvile.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: I tell you, sir, it is no little grief to me you should so hardly conceit of my daughter, whose honest report, though I say it, was never blotted with any title of defamation.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Father Miller, the repair of those gentlemen to your house hath given me great occasion to mislike.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: As for those gentlemen, I never saw in them any evil entreaty. But should they have proffered it, her chaste mind hath proof enough to prevent it.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Those gentlemen are as honest as ever I saw; for, i’faith, one of them gave me sixpence to fetch a quart of sack. See, master, here they come.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Trotter, call Em. Now they are here together, I’ll have the matter thoroughly debated.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Father, well met. We are come to confer with you.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Nay, with his daughter, rather.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Thus it is, father, we are come to crave your friendship in a matter.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Gentlemen, as you are strangers to me, yet, by the way of courtesy, you shall demand any reasonable thing at my hands.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: What, is the matter so forward they came to crave his goodwill?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: It is given us to understand that your daughter is suddenly become both blind and deaf.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Marry, God forbid! I have sent for her; indeed, she hath kept her chamber this three days. It were no little grief to me if it should be so.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: This is God’s judgment for her treachery!

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Gentlemen, I fear your words are too true. See where Trotter comes leading of her. What ails my Em? Not blind, I hope?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Mountney and Vallingford both together! And Manvile, to whom I have faithfully vowed my love! Now, Em, suddenly help thyself.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: This is no dissembling, Vallingford.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: If it be, it is cunningly contrived of all sides.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Trotter, lend me thy hand; and as thou lovest me, keep my counsel, and justify whatsoever I say, and I’ll largely requite thee.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Ah, that’s as much as to say you would tell a monstrous, terrible, horrible, outrageous lie, and I shall sooth it; no, by our lady!

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: My present extremity wills me, if thou love me, Trotter.

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: That same word, love, makes me to do anything.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Trotter, where’s my father?

speech.speaker: TROT.
speech.line: Why, what a blind dunce are you, can you not see? He standeth right before you.

stagedir.dir: He thrusts Em upon her Father.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Is this my father? Good father, give me leave to sit where I may not be disturbed, sith God hath visited me both of my sight and hearing.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Tell me, sweet Em, how came this blindness? Thy eyes are lovely to look on, and yet have they lost the benefit of their sight. What a grief is this to thy poor father!

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Good father, let me not stand as an open gazing stock to every one, but in a place alone, as fits a creature so miserable.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Trotter, lead her in. The utter overthrow of poor Goddard’s joy and only solace!

stagedir.dir: Exit the Miller, Trotter, and Em.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Both blind and deaf! Then is she no wife for me and glad am I so good an occasion is happened. Now will I away to Manchester, and leave these gentlemen to their blind fortune.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Since fortune hath thus spitefully crossed our hope, let us leave this quest, and hearken after our king, who at this day is landed at Liverpool.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Go, my lord, I’ll follow you. Well, now Mountney is gone, I’ll stay behind to solicit my love. For I imagine that I shall find this but a feigned invention, thereby to have us leave off our suits.

stagedir.dir: Enter Marquis of Lubeck and the King of Denmark, angrily, with some Attendants.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Well, Lubeck, well, it is not possible
But you must be consenting to this act.
Is this the man so highly you extolled?
And play a part so hateful with his friend?
Since first he came with thee into the court,
What entertainment and what countenance
He hath received, none better knows than thou.
In recompense whereof, he quits me well,
To steal away fair Mariana my prisoner,
Whose ransom being lately ’greed upon,
I am deluded of by this escape.
Besides, I know not how to answer it,
When she shall be demanded home to Swethia.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: My gracious lord, conjecture not, I pray,
Worser of Lubeck than he doth deserve:
Your highness knows Mariana was my love,
Sole paragon and mistress of my thoughts.
Is’t likely I should know of her departure,
Wherein there’s no man injured more than I?

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: That carries reason, Marquis, I confess.
Call forth my daughter; yet I am persuaded
That she, poor soul, suspected not her going;
For as I hear, she likewise loved the man,
Which he, to blame, did not at all regard.

speech.speaker: ROZ.
speech.line: My lord, here is the princess Mariana;
It is your daughter is conveyed away.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: What! My daughter gone?
Now, Marquis, now your villainy breaks forth;
This match is of your making, gentle sir,
And you shall dearly know the price thereof.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Knew I thereof, or that there was intent
In Robert thus to steal your highness’ daughter,
Let heavens in justice presently confound me!

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Not all the protestations thou canst use
Shall save thy life. Away with him to prison!
And, minion, otherwise it cannot be
But you are an agent in this treachery:
I will revenge it thoroughly on you both.
Away with her to prison!
Here’s stuff indeed! My daughter stolen away!
It booteth not thus to disturb myself,
But presently to send to English William,
To send me that proud knight of Windsor hither,
Here in my court to suffer for his shame,
Or at my pleasure to be punished there,
Withal that Blanch be sent me home again,
Or I shall fetch her unto Windsor’s cost;
Yea, and William’s, too, if he deny her me.

scene.scenelocation: England. The camp of the Earl of Dimarch.

stagedir.dir: Enter William the Conqueror, taken with Soldiers.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Could any cross, could any plague be worse?
Could heaven or hell, did both conspire in one
To afflict my soul, invent a greater scourge
Than presently I am tormented with?
Ah, Mariana, cause of my lament!
Joy of my heart, and comfort of my life,
For thee I breathe my sorrows in the air
And tire myself, for silently I sigh,
My sorrows affect my soul with equal passion.

speech.speaker: SOLD.
speech.line: Go to, sirrah, put up, it is to small purpose.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Hence, villains, hence! Dare you lay your hands
Upon your sovereign?

speech.speaker: SOLD.
speech.line: Well, sir, we will deal for that;
But here comes one will remedy all this.
My lord, watching this night in the camp,
We took this man, and know not what he is;
And in his company was a gallant dame,
A woman fair in outward show she seemed,
But that her face was masked, we could not see
The grace and favor of her countenance.

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: Tell me, good fellow, of whence and what art thou?

speech.speaker: SOLD.
speech.line: Why do you not answer my lord?
He takes scorn to answer!

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: And tak’st thou scorn to answer my demand?
Thy proud behavior very well deserves
This misdemeanor at the worst be construed.
Why, dost thou neither know, nor hast thou heard,
That in the absence of the Saxon duke,
Dimarch is his especial substitute,
To punish those that shall offend the laws?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: In knowing this, I know thou art a traitor;
A rebel, and mutinous conspirator.
Why, Dimarch, knowest thou who I am?

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: Pardon, my dread lord, the error of my sense,
And misdemeanor to your princely excellency!

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Why, Dimarch, what is the cause my subjects are in arms?

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: Free are my thoughts, my dread and gracious lord,
From treason to your state and commonweal;
Only revengement of a private grudge,
By Lord Dirot lately proffered me,
That stands not with the honor of my name,
Is cause I have assembled for my guard
Some men in arms, that may withstand his force,
Whose settled malice aimeth at my life.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Where’s Lord Dirot?

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: In arms, my gracious lord,
Not past two miles from hence,
As credibly I am ascertained.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Well, come, let’s go,
I fear I shall find traitors of you both.

scene.scenelocation: Manchester. The garden before the house of a Citizen.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Citizen, and his daughter Elner, and Manvile.

speech.speaker: CIT.
speech.line: Indeed, sir, it would do very well if you could entreat your father to come hither. But if you think it be too far, I care not much to take horse and ride to Manchester. I am sure my daughter is content with either. How sayest thou, Elner, art thou not?

speech.speaker: ELNER.
speech.line: As you shall think best, I must be contented.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Well, Elner, farewell. Only thus much I pray: make all things in a readiness, either to serve here, or to carry thither with us.

speech.speaker: CIT.
speech.line: As for that, sir, take you no care, and so I betake you to your journey.
But soft, what gentleman is this?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: God speed, sir. Might a man crave a word or two with you?

speech.speaker: CIT.
speech.line: God forbid else, sir; I pray you speak your pleasure.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: The gentleman that parted from you, was he not of Manchester, his father living there of good account?

speech.speaker: CIT.
speech.line: Yes, marry is he, sir. Why do you ask? Belike you have had some acquaintance with him?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I have been acquainted, in times past, but, through his double dealing, I am grown weary of his company. For be it spoken to you, he hath been acquainted with a poor miller’s daughter, and divers times hath promised her marriage, but what with his delays and flouts, he hath brought her into such a taking that I fear me it will cost her her life.

speech.speaker: CIT.
speech.line: To be plain with you, sir, his father and I have been of old acquaintance, and a motion was made between my daughter and his son, which now is thoroughly agreed upon, save only the place appointed for the marriage, whether it shall be kept here or at Manchester, and for no other occasion he is now ridden.

speech.speaker: ELNER.
speech.line: What hath he done to you, that you should speak so ill of the man?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Oh, gentlewoman, I cry you mercy. He is your husband that shall be.

speech.speaker: ELNER.
speech.line: If I knew this to be true, he should not be my husband were he never so good. And therefore, good father, I would desire you to take the pains to bear this gentleman company to Manchester, to know whether this be true or no.

speech.speaker: CIT.
speech.line: Now trust me, gentleman, he deals with me very hardly, knowing how well I meant to him. But I care not much to ride to Manchester, to know whether his father’s will be he should deal with me so badly. Will it please you, sir, to go in? We will presently take horse and away.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: If it please you to go in, I’ll follow you presently.
Now shall I be revenged on Manvile, and by this means get Em to be my wife. And therefore I will straight to her father’s and inform them both of all that has happened.

scene.scenelocation: England. A room of state in the palace of William the Conqueror.

stagedir.dir: Enter William the Conqueror, the Ambassador of Denmark, Dimarch, and other Attendants.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: What news with the Denmark ambassador?

speech.speaker: DAN. AMB.
speech.line: Marry, thus: the king of Denmark, and my sovereign,
Doth send to know of thee what is the cause,
That, injuriously, against the law of arms,
Thou hast stolen away his only daughter, Blanch,
The only stay and comfort of his life?
Therefore, by me
He willeth thee to send his daughter Blanch,
Or else forthwith he will levy such an host,
As soon shall fetch her in despite of thee.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Ambassador, this answer I return thy king—
He willeth me to send his daughter Blanch,
Saying I conveyed her from the Danish court,
That never yet once did as think thereof.
As for his menacing and daunting threats,
I will regard him nor his Danish power;
For if he come to fetch her forth my realm,
I will provide him such a banquet here,
That he shall have small cause to give me thanks.

speech.speaker: DAN. AMB.
speech.line: Is this your answer, then?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: It is; and so begone.

speech.speaker: DAN. AMB.
speech.line: I go; but to your cost.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Dimarch,
Our subjects, erst levied in civil broils,
Muster forthwith for to defend the realm;
In hope whereof that we shall find you true,
We freely pardon this thy late offense.

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: Most humble thanks I render to your grace.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Alas, gentleman, why should you trouble yourself so much, considering the imperfections of my daughter, which is able to withdraw the love of any man from her, as already it hath done in her first choice. Master Manvile hath forsaken her, and at Chester shall be married to a man’s daughter of no little wealth. But if my daughter knew so much, it would go very near her heart, I fear me.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Father miller, such is my entire affection to your daughter, as no misfortune whatsoever can alter. My fellow, Mountney, thou seest, gave quickly over, but I, by reason of my good meaning, am not so soon to be changed, although I am borne off with scorns and denial.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Trust me, sir, I know not what to say. My daughter is not to be compelled by me. But here she comes herself. Speak to her and spare not, for I never was troubled with love matters so much before.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Good Lord! Shall I never be rid of this importunate man? Now must I dissemble blindness again. Once more for thy sake, Manvile, thus am I enforced, because I shall complete my full resolved mind to thee.
Father, where are you?

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Here, sweet Em. Answer this gentleman, that would so fain enjoy thy love.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Where are you, sir? Will you never leave this idle and vain pursuit of love? Is not England stord enough to content you, but you must still trouble the poor contemptible maid of Manchester?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: None can content me but the fair maid of Manchester.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: I perceive love is vainly described, that, being blind himself, would have you likewise troubled with a blind wife, having the benefit of your eyes. But neither follow him so much in folly, but love one in whom you may better delight.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Father miller, thy daughter shall have honor by granting me her love. I am a gentleman of King William’s court, and no mean man in King William’s favor.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: If you be a lord, sir, as you say, you offer both yourself and me great wrong. Yours, as apparent, in limiting your love so unorderly, for which you rashly endure reproachment mine, as open and evident, when, being shut out from the vanities of this world, you would have me as an open gazing-stock to all the world. For lust, not love, leads you into this error. But from the one I will keep me as well as I can. And yield the other to none but to my father, as I am bound by duty.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Why, fair Em, Manvile hath forsaken thee, and must at Chester be married. Which if I speak otherwise than true, let thy father speak what credibly he hath heard.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: But can it be, Manvile will deal so unkindly to reward my justice with such monstrous ungentleness? Have I dissembled for thy sake, and dost thou now thus requite it? Indeed, these many days I have not seen him, which hath made me marvel at his long absence.
But, father, are you assured of the words he spake were concerning Manvile?

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: In sooth, daughter, now it is forth, I must needs confirm it: Master Manvile hath forsaken thee, and at Chester must be married to a man’s daughter of no little wealth. His father procures it, and therefore I dare credit it; and do thou believe it; for trust me, daughter, it is so.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Then, good father, pardon the injury that I have done to you, only causing your grief by overfond affecting a man so trothless. And you likewise, sir, I pray hold me excused, as I hope this cause will allow sufficiently for me; my love to Manvile, thinking he would requite it, hath made me double with my father and you, and many more besides, which I will no longer hide from you. That enticing speeches should not beguile me, I have made myself deaf to any but to him; and lest any man’s person should please me more than his, I have dissembled the want of my sight. Both which shadows of my irrevocable affections I have not spared to confirm before him, my father, and all other amorous solicitors; wherewith not made acquainted, I perceive my true intent hath wrought mine own sorrow, and seeking by love to be regarded, am cut off with contempt, and despised.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Tell me, sweet Em, hast thou but feigned all this while for his love, that hath so discourteously forsaken thee?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Credit me, father, I have told you the truth. Wherewith I desire you and Lord Vallingford not to be displeased. For aught else I shall say, let my present grief hold me excused. But may I live to see that ungrateful man justly rewarded for his treachery, poor Em would think herself not a little happy. Favor my departing at this instant, for my troubled thought desires to meditate alone in silence.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Will not Em show one cheerful look on Vallingford?

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Alas, sir, blame her not. You see she hath good cause, being so handled by this gentleman. And so I’ll leave you, and go comfort my poor wench as well as I may.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Farewell, good father.

scene.scenelocation: England. An open space prepared for the meeting of William the Conqueror and Zweno the Danish King.

stagedir.dir: Enter King of Denmark with Rozilio and other Attendants.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Rocilio, is this the place whereas
The Duke William should meet me?

speech.speaker: ROZ.
speech.line: It is, and like your grace.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Go, captain, away; regard the charge I gave:
See all our men be marshalled for the fight;
Dispose the wards, as lately was devised,
And let the prisoners, under several guards,
Be kept apart until you hear from us.
Let this suffice—you know my resolution;
If William, Duke of Saxon, be the man,
That by his answer sent us, he would send
Not words, but wounds; not parleys, but alarms
Must be decider of this controversy.
Rozilio, stay with me, the rest begone.

stagedir.dir: Enter William the Conqueror and Dimarch with other Attendants.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: All but Dimarch go shroud you out of sight;
For I’ll go parley with the prince myself.

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: Should Zweno, by this parley, call you forth,
Upon intent injuriously to deal,
This offereth too much opportunity.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: No, no, Dimarch,
That were a breach against the law of arms;
Therefore begone, and leave us here alone.
I see that Zweno is master of his word.

stagedir.dir: Re-enter King of Denmark and Rozilio.

speech.line: Zweno, William of Saxony greeteth thee,
Either well or ill, according to thy intent.
If well thou wish to him and Saxony,
He bids thee friendly welcome as he can;
If ill thou wish to him and Saxony,
He must withstand thy malice as he may.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: William, for other name and title give I none
To him, who, were he worthy of those honors
That fortune and his predecessors left,
I ought, by right and human courtsey,
To grace his style with Duke of Saxony.
But, for I find a base, degenerate mind,
I frame my speech according to the man,
And not the state that he unworthy holds.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Herein, Zweno, dost thou abase thy state,
To break the peace which by our ancestors
Hath heretofore been honorably kept.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: And should that peace for ever have been kept
Had not thyself been author of the breach;
Nor stands it with the honor of my state,
Or nature of a father to his child,
That I should so be robbed of my daughter,
And not unto the utmost of my power,
Revenge so intolerable an injury.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Is this the color of your quarrel, Zweno?
I well perceive the wisest men may err:—
And think you I conveyed away you daughter Blanch?

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Art thou so impudent to deny thou didst,
When that the proof thereof is manifest?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: What proof is there?

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Thine own confession is sufficient proof.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Did I confess I stole your daughter Blanch?

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Thou didst confess thou hadst a lady hence.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: I have, and do.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Why, that was Blanch my daughter.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Nay, that was Mariana;
Who wrongfully thou detainest prisoner.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Shameless persisting in thy ill!
Thou dost maintain a manifest untruth,
As she shall justify unto thy teeth.
Rocilio, fetch her and the marquis hither.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: It cannot be I should be so deceived.

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: I heard this night among the soldiers,
That in their watch they took a pensive lady,
Who, at th’appointment of the Lord Dirot,
Is yet in keeping. What she is, I know not;
Only thus much I overheard by chance.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: And what of this?

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: It may be Blanch, the King of Denmark’s daughter.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: It may be so; but on my life it is not:
Yet, Dimarch, go and fetch her straight.

stagedir.dir: Re-enter Rozilio with the Marquis and Mariana.

speech.speaker: ROZ.
speech.line: Pleaseth your highness, here is the Marquis and Mariana.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: See here, Duke William, your competitors,
That were consenting to my daughter’s ’scape:
Let them resolve you of the truth herein,
And here I vow and solemnly protest,
That in thy presence they shall lose their heads,
Unless I hear whereas my daughter is.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Oh, Marquis Lubeck, how it grieveth me
That for my sake thou shouldst endure these bonds!
Be judge, my soul, that feels the martyrdom!

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Duke William, you know it’s for your cause
It pleaseth thus the king to misconceive of me,
And for his pleasure doth me injury.

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: May it please your highness,
Here is the lady whom you sent me for.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Away, Dimarch, what tell’st thou me of ladies?
I so detest the dealing of their sex,
As that I count a lover’s state to be
The base and vildest slavery in the world!

speech.speaker: DIM.
speech.line: What humors are these? Here’s a strange alteration!

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: See, Duke William, is this Blanch or no?
You know her if you see her, I am sure.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Zweno, I was deceived, yea, utterly deceived;
Yet this is she: this same is Lady Blanch:
And for mine error here I am content
To do whatever Zweno shall set down.
Ah, cruel Mariana, thus to use
The man which loved and honored thee with’s heart!

speech.speaker: MARI.
speech.line: When first I came into your highness’ court,
And William oft importing me of love,
I did devise, to ease the grief your daughter did sustain,
She should meet Sir William masked, as I it were.
This put in proof did take so good effect,
As yet it seems his grace is not resolved,
But it was I which he conveyed away.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: May this be true? It cannot be but true.
Was’t Lady Blanch which I conveyed away?
Unconstant Mariana, thus to deal
With him which meant to thee nought but faith!

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: Pardon, dear father, my follies that are past,
Wherein I have neglected my duty,
Which I in reverence ought to shew your grace;
For led by love I thus have gone astray,
And now repent the errors I was in.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Stand up, dear daughter. Though thy fault deserves
For to be punished in the extremest sort,
Yet love, that covers multitude of sins,
Makes love in parents wink at children’s faults.
Sufficeth, Blanch, thy father loves thee so,
Thy follies past he knows, but will not know.
And here, Duke William, take my daughter to thy wife,
For well I am assured she loves thee well.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: A proper conjunction!
As who should say, lately come out of the fire,
I would go thrust myself into the flame.
Let Mistress Nice go saint it where she list,
And coyly quaint it with dissembling face;
I hold in scorn the fooleries that they use:
I being free, will ne’er subject myself
To any such as she is underneath the sun.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Refusest thou to take my daughter to thy wife?
I tell thee, duke, this rash denial may bring
More mischief on thee than thou canst avoid.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Conceit hath wrought such general dislike,
Through the false dealing of Mariana,
That utterly I do abhor their sex;
They’re all disloyal, unconstant, all unjust;
Who tries as I have tried, and finds as I have found,
Will say there’s no such creatures on the ground.

speech.speaker: BLANCH.
speech.line: Unconstant knight, though some deserve no trust,
There’s others faithful, loving, loyal, and just!

stagedir.dir: Enter Vallingford, with Em and the Miller, Mountney, Manvile, and Elner.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: How now, Lord Vallingford, what makes these women here?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Here be two women, may it please your grace,
That are contracted to one man, and are
In strife whether shall have him to her husband.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Stand forth, women, and say
To whether of you did he first give his faith.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: To me, forsooth.

speech.speaker: ELNER.
speech.line: To me, my gracious lord.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Speak, Manvile; to whether didst thou give thy faith?

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: To say the truth, this maid had first my love.

speech.speaker: ELNER.
speech.line: Yes, Manvile, but there was no witness by.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Thy conscience, Manvile, is a thousand witnesses.

speech.speaker: ELNER.
speech.line: She hath stolen a conscience to serve her own turn;
But you are deceived, i’faith, he will none of you.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Indeed, dread lord, so dear I held her love,
As in the same I put my whole delight;
But some impediments, which at that instant
Happened, made me forsake her quite;
For which I had her father’s frank consent.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: What were the impediments?

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Why, she could neither hear nor see.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Now she doth both. Maiden, how were you cured?

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Pardon, my lord, I’ll tell your grace the truth,
Be it not imputed to me as discredit.
I loved this Manvile so much, that still methought,
When he was absent, did present to me
The form and feature of that countenance
Which I did shrine an idol in my heart;
And never could I see a man, methought,
That equalled Manvile in my partial eye.
Nor was there any love between us lost,
But that I held the same in high regard,
Until repair of some unto our house,
Of whom my Manvile grew thus jealous;
As if he took exception I vouchsafed
To hear them speak, or saw them when they came;
On which I straight took order with myself
To void the scruple of his conscience,
By counterfeiting that I neither saw nor heard,
Anyways to rid my hands of them.
All this I did to keep my Manvile’s love,
Which he unkindly seeks for to reward.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: And did my Em, to keep her faith with me,
Dissemble that she neither heard nor saw?
Pardon me, sweet Em, for I am only thine!

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Lay off thy hands, disloyal as thou art!
Nor shalt thou have possession of my love,
That canst so finely shift thy matters off.
Put case I had been blind and could not see,
As oftentimes such visitations fall,
That pleaseth God, which all things doth dispose,
Shouldst thou forsake me in regard of that?
I tell thee, Manvile, hadst thou been blind,
Or deaf or dumb, or what impediments
Else might befall to man,
Em would have loved, and kept, and honored thee;
Yea, begged, if wealth had failed, for thy relief.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Forgive me, sweet Em!

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: I do forgive thee with my heart,
And will forget thee too, if case I can;
But never speak to me, nor seem to know me.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Then farewell frost! Well fare a wench that will!
Now, Elner, I’m thine own, my girl.

speech.speaker: ELNER.
speech.line: Mine, Manvile? Thou never shalt be mine;
I so detest thy villainy,
That whilst I live I will abhor thy company.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Is it come to this? Of late I had choice of twain,
On either side, to have me to her husband,
And now am utterly rejected of them both.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: My lord, this gentleman, when time was,
Stood something in our light,
And now I think it not amiss
To laugh at him that sometime scorned at us.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: Content, my lord, invent the form.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Then thus—

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: I see that women are not general evils—
Blanch is fair; methinks I see in her
A modest countenance, a heavenly blush.
Zweno, receive a reconcilèd foe,
Not as thy friend, but as thy son-in-law,
If so that thou be thus content.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: I joy to see your grace so tractable:—
Here, take my daughter Blanch,
And after my decease the Denmark crown.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Now, sir, how stands the case with you?

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: I partly am persuaded as your grace is—
My lord, he’s best at ease that meddleth least.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Sir, may a man be so bold
As to crave a word with you?

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Yea, two or three. What are they?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: I say, this maid will have thee to her husband.

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: And I say this: and therefore will I lay
A hundred pound.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: And I say this: whereon I’ll lay as much.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: And I say neither: what say you to that?

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: If that be true, then are we both deceived.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Why, it is true, and you are both deceived.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: In mine eyes, this is the properest wench.
Might I advise thee, take her to thy wife?

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: It seems to me she hath refused him.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: Why, there’s the spite.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: If one refuse him, yet may he have the other.

speech.speaker: LUB.
speech.line: He’ll ask but her good will, and all her friends.

speech.speaker: ZWENO.
speech.line: Might I advise thee? Let them both alone.

speech.speaker: MANV.
speech.line: Yea, that’s the course, and thereon will I stand;
Such idle love henceforth I will detest.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: The fox will eat no grapes, and why?

speech.speaker: MOUNT.
speech.line: I know, full well, because they hang too high.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: And may’t be a miller’s daughter by her birth?
I cannot think but she is better born.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Sir Thomas Goddard hight this reverend man,
Famed for his virtues, and his good success;
Whose fame hath been renownèd through the world.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Sir Thomas Goddard, welcome to thy prince,
And fair Em, frolic with thy good father.
As glad am I to find Sir Thomas Goddard,
As good Sir Edmund Treford, on the plains;
He like a shepherd, and thou our country miller.

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: And longer let not Goddard live a day,
Then he in honor loves his sovereign.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: But say, Sir Thomas, shall I give thy daughter?

speech.speaker: MILL.
speech.line: Sir Thomas Goddard, and all that he hath,
Doth rest at the pleasure of your majesty.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: And what says Em to lovely Vallingford?
It seemed he loved you well, that for your sake
Durst leave his king.

speech.speaker: EM.
speech.line: Em rests at the pleasure of your highness;
And would I were a wife for his desert.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Then here, Lord Vallingford, receive fair Em.
Here take her, make her thy espousèd wife.
Then go we in, that preparation may be made,
To see these nuptials solemnly performed.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt. Flourish of drums and trumpets.
